results.title: Water
results.brief_description: This film is concerned with the chemical aspects of water. Pure water mever occurs in nature, since water is the universal solvent. The percentage of water in man, in a fish, in a lettuce, and in a water lily are demonstrated. The formation of stalagtites and stalacmites in caves in limestone hills is compared with the furring of hot-water pipes and kettles, both being gradually formed deposits left behind by water. Some of the chemicals in water are needed by humans, since they are useful in building up body tissues. The film ends with a short summing up of the importance of work done by research scientists and chemists who are constantly studying the constituents of water.

results.title: Water
results.creator_credit: United Nations Environment Programme, Dick Young Productions and Dick Young
results.brief_description: Shows the importance of water in man’s existence in all parts of the world, including Africa, India and Asia. Covers social issues such as water pollution, lack of water for human consumption in the dry arid areas and the need for developing international cooperation in relation to water usage and conservation of this natural resource. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Water
results.creator_credit: United Nations, Columbia University Center for Mass Communications, Dorothy Oshlag and Philip Stapp
results.brief_description: World-wide water shortage. Today increased demands for water and increased pollutions of rivers have brought us to the verge of a world-wide water crisis. Using unusual animation techniques, this interesting film outlines the problem and stresses the need for international control and co-operation. Scans the many difficulties which surround the provision of adequate clean water to the growing world population, for agriculture, industry and health.

results.title: Watching them write, seeing them learn: a kindergarten writing community at work
results.creator_credit: Riverina College of Advanced Education. Literacy Centre and Brian Butler
results.brief_description: Kindergarten children experiment with written language. There are no formal writing lessons and they are left free to learn by trial and error. Narrated by Barbara Kamler.

results.title: Watching ballet

results.title: Watch with mother 2
results.brief_description: A classic collection of five British children’s television programs from the series “Watch with mother” screened to the first children of the television age during the 50s and 60s. Monday - “Picture book: Bush-baby” (transmitted 19 August 1963): Hosted and narrated by Vera McKechnie, along with ‘Sausage’ the dog, (a string puppet) includes a nature segment, animated storytelling and creative activities with a sandbox. Tuesday - “Andy Pandy: The Cart” (transmitted 8 July 1952): Stars string puppet Andy Pandy and his friends and features some real live fluffy ducklings in this short story. Wednesday - “Flower Pot Men: The Potato man” (transmitted 4 October 1953): A combined animated/live action story starring those two very famous puppets who live in flower pots, Bill and Ben. Thursday - “Rag, Tag and Bobtail: Snowballs” (transmitted 25 November 1954): Features hand puppets, Rag the hedgehog, Tag the little mouse and Bobtail the rabbit as they discover the delights of the snowball flower. Friday - “The Woodentops: Horseshoe” (transmitted 14 March 1958): Features the wooden string puppets of the ‘Woodentop’ family - mum, dad, baby, Willie and Jenny the twins, Mrs Scrubit who comes to help the Woodentops, Sam who helps dad, Spotty the dog and Dobbin the horse. These five 15 minute puppet shows are all filmed in b&w and are suitable for pre-schoolers and lower primary school level.

results.title: Watch us move (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles and Richard Beindorf
results.brief_description: Introduces sensory motor concepts for training preschool retarded children. Discusses a program at a day school, describing the need for sensory integration and demonstrating the effects of the program on the children. Produced by the Child Mental Health Nursing Program UCSF.
